dialogue:
Person1: Yes. I took refuge in the barn. Wouldn't you? Lost in the storm? Freezing and wet? I was exhausted and could search no longer.
Person2: And is it true, Miss Moritz, that you love Victor Frankenstein? That your heart was broken?  Answer the question. Do you love Victor Frankenstein?

Person1: I still don't know what you're getting at. Right now I want to take my nap. It's important that I-
Person2: - it's important right now that we talk. Killer to killer.
Person1: Champion to champion.
Person2: Not with me, you're no champion. You're stepping way up in class.
Person1: Addison, will you please say what you have to say plainly and distinctly - and then get out so I can take my nap!
Person2: Very well, plainly and distinctly. Although I consider it unnecessary - because you know as well as I, what I am about to say.  Lloyd may leave Karen, but he will not leave Karen for you.
Person1: What do you mean by that?
Person2: More plainly and more distinctly? I Have not come to New Haven to see the play, discuss your dreams, or to pull the ivy from the walls of Yale! I have come to tell you that you will not marry Lloyd - or anyone else - because I will not permit it.
Person1: What have you got to do with it?
Person2: Everything. Because after tonight, you will belong to me.
Person1: I can't believe my ears...
Person2: A dull cliche.
Person1: Belong - to you? That sound medieval - something out of an old melodrama...
Person2: So does the history of the world for the past twenty years. I don't enjoy putting it as bluntly as this, frankly I had hoped that you would, somehow, have known - have taken it for granted that you and I...
Person1: ... taken it for granted? That you and I...

Person1: Look, I just thought if you finally got rid of this obsession with this name, if you could get it out of your system once and for all, then maybe you'd be able to stop waiting and open your heart to someone real.  Granted, ideally, me.  I didn't do it to hurt you.  I did it for you.  I did it for us...
Person2: There is no us.

Person1: You want me to dress like her?
Person2: Judy, I just want you to look nice. And I know what kind of suit would look well on you.
Person1: Ah, no!!! I don't want to be dressed like someone dead!
Person2: Judy --
Person1: It's a horrible idea! Is that what I'm here for? To make you feel that you're with someone that's dead?

Person1: It's true.
Person2: I'm tryin' to keep you from being hurt What more do you want?
Person1: Much more, Terry. Much, much more!

Person1: If you're determined to revive the crew now, I can handle the whole thing myself. There's no need for you to trouble.
Person2: I'm goin to do this myself, Hal. Let me have the control, please.
Person1: Look, Dave your've probably got a lot to do. I suggest you leave it to me.
Person2: Hal, switch to manual hibernation control.
Person1: I don't like to assert myself, Dave, but it would be much better now for you to rest. You've been involved in a very stressful situation.

Person1: I got something for you to do tomorrow.
Person2: I kind of had plans....
Person1: Sailing?  Forget it.  You're beached. Grounded.  No more boats.
Person2: Hey, come on....
Person1: No backtalk!  I spoke to Upton, at the beach, and he's got a job for you there.  You can work until school starts.

Person1: I'm thinking of selling the old family cabin.
Person2: That cabin has been in our family for generations. If you sell it, you'll regret it.
Person1: The maintenance costs are piling up, and nobody uses it anymore.
Person2: It's not just about money, Ella. It's about our heritage and memories.
Person1: I understand that, but sometimes we need to let go of the past.

Person1: You know, you've been very nervous lately.
Person2: I can't take this anymore.
Person1: I'm just trying to complete an education I started on you five years ago.
Person2: I'm not your pupil.  I was, but I'm not.
Person1: When you leave the nest, I just want you to be ready to face the real world.

Person1: I don't need that, Buddy.  I'm not Jack Kennedy.
Person2: No, you're not.  So stop comparing yourself to him.  You have no reason to ... You have everything you ever wanted. You've earned it.  Why can't you just enjoy it?
Person1: I do.  I do.  In my own way.
Person2: Then what are you scared of, honey?
Person1: I'm not scared, Buddy.  You don't understand.  They're playing for keeps, Buddy.  The press, the kids, the liberals -- they're out there, trying to figure out how to tear me down.
Person2: They're all your enemies?
Person1: Yes!
Person2: You personally?
Person1: Yes!  This is about me.  Why can't you understand that, you of all people? It's not the war -- it's Nixon!  They want to destroy Nixon!  And if I expose myself even the slightest bit they'll tear my insides out.  Do you want that?  Do you want to see that, Buddy?  It's not pretty.
Person2: Sometimes I think that's what you want.
Person1: You've been drinking.  What the hell are you saying?  Jesus, you sound like them now! ...  I've gotta keep fighting, Buddy, for the country.  These people running things, the elite ... they're soft, chickenshit faggots!  They don't have the long-term vision anymore.  They just want to cover their asses or meet girls or tear each other down.  Oh, God, this country's in deep trouble, Buddy ... and I have to see this through.  Mother would've wanted no less of me ... I'm sorry, Buddy.

Person1: Why did you decide without asking me?
Person2: I was only trying to do what I thought was best.
Person1: Your decisions affect both of us. You should have consulted me.
Person2: I know. I'll be more considerate next time.
Person1: That's all I ask.

Person1: You said we do appearances together, or not at all.'
Person2: I didn't say that.  I said "wouldn't it be great if we could always, work together." That's what I said.

Person1: Is this my fault? Do you think this is what I am?
Person2: What?
Person1: This is not me! I am a professional thief. I steal money. You try to stop me, god help you. But I don't kill people I don't have to, and I don't rape women. What you doin' ain't how it's done. Do you understand?
Person2: Seth, if you were me --
Person1: Just say yes! Nothing else, just say yes.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Yes, Seth, I understand.
Person2: Yes, Seth, I understand.

Person1: He knew about Sammy. Why would I tell him about Sammy?
Person2: You tell everyone about Sammy. Everyone who'll listen. "Remember Sammy Jankis, remember Sammy Jankis". Great story. Gets better every time you tell it. So you lie to yourself to be happy. Nothing wrong with that - we all do. Who cares if there's a few little things you'd rather not remember?
Person1: What are you talking about?

Person1: Yo soy un hombre sincero...; I am a sincere man, From the land of the palms...
Person2: What's that?
Person1: The song.  Are you sincere with me, Fredo?
Person2: Sincere.  What are you talking about, of course I'm sincere with you, Mike.
Person1: Then I'm going to confide in you; trust you with something.
Person2: Mike, are you crazy, I'm your brother.
Person1: Tonight we've been invited to a reception at the Presidential Palace; to bring in the New Year. You and I will go in a special car that's being sent.  They'll have cocktails... then dinner, and a reception with the President.  When it's over, it will be suggested that you take Questadt and his friends from Washington to spend the night with some women.  I'll go home alone in the car; and before I reach the hotel, I'll be assassinated.
Person2: ...Who?
Person1: The same man who tried in Nevada... Hyman Roth, not Pentangeli.
Person2: But, you told me yourself...
Person1: It was never Pentangeli... I've always known that.  It was Roth all along.  He talks to me as a son; as his successor, but the old man thinks he'll live forever.
Person2: What do you want me to do?
Person1: To go tonight, with me, as though we know nothing.  I've already made my move.
Person2: What is it?  Can I help?
Person1: The old man will never bring in the New Year.

Person1: Chopin prelude.  Stodgy, but nice.  Here's the deal.  I didn't want you involved in this.  Still breathing? But now that you are, we have to make the best of it, Max.  Improvise.  Life is that way.  Adapt to your environment.  Survive.  Darwin.  "Shit happens."  The I Ching.  Whatever. Roll with it.
Person2: I Ching?  You threw a man out a window!
Person1: I didn't throw him, he fell.
Person2: What'd he do to you?
Person1: Nothing.  I only met him the one time.
Person2: How can you kill him like that?
Person1: I should only kill people after I get to know 'em?  Six billion people on the planet, you're getting bent out of shape 'cause of one fat guy?
Person2: Who was he?
Person1: What do you care?  Ever hear of Rwanda?
Person2: Rwanda-Burundi.  Central Africa.
Person1: Tens of thousands killed before sundown.  Nobody's killed that fast since Hiroshima and Nagasaki.  Did you bat an eye, Max?  Join Amnesty International?  No.  I off one Angeleno, you throw a hissy fit...

Person1: ...See you tomorrow night.
Person2: Include me out.  I've had enough of the conversations.
Person1: You don't mean that.  You wouldn't disappoint Daddy --
Person2: Daddy'll do fine.  Besides, he's got Joe.  And so do you.
Person1: Drew, you're out of line.
Person2: That may be.  But I don't like that guy.  I don't like the way he looks at you and talks to you.  And vice versa.
Person1: Sorry, but I like the way he looks and talks to me.  And vice versa. Okay?
Person2: No, not okay.  I thought we had a good thing going here.  It shows you never know.

Person1: Do not lecture me about treaty violations. The Federation, in creating an ultimate weapon, has become a gang of Intergalactic criminals. It is not I who will surrender, it is you.  On the planet below, I have three prisoners from the team who developed your doomsday weapon. If you do not surrender immediately, I will execute them, one at a time, as enemies of galactic peace.
Person2: Who is this?! How dare you --
Person1: Who I am is not important. That I have them is.  I will let you speak to them.

Person1: Mick.  Mick.  Mick...
Person2: What?
Person1: You -- Listen. You said to me, if not now, when...
Person2: I know what I said but not now. You won it.  Franky.  You won it. When they give you the money, that means that you won.  We don't want to go to court -- is this getting to you...?  You know who the attorney is for the Archdiocese, Eddie Concannon.
Person1: ...he's a good man...
Person2: ...he's a good man...?  He's the Prince of Darkness...he'll have people in there testifying that the broad is well -- they saw her Tuesday on a surfboard at Hyannis...don't mess with this case.
Person1: ...I have to stand up for her...
Person2: Frank, but not now.  Frank.  You're trying to wipe out some old business.  But not now.  I understand.  But you go call 'em back.  You call the Bishop back.
Person1: I have to try this case.  I have to do it, Mick.  I've got to stand up for that girl.  I need your help.    Mick, will you help me...?    Will you help me...?

Person1: Let me tell him.  Let him decide.
Person2: You're not gonna see him again.
Person1: What... what makes you think you can order me around?!
Person2: Maybe I'm not making myself clear. You're probably the first girl Billy-Boy's ever fallen in love with, and I know for sure you're the first he's slept with.  So, how's he gonna feel...  ... when he finds out that the only first he is for you is the first guy who didn't have to pull out at the last second to get his close-up?

Person1: Every time I tell you that I love you, you flinch. But that's your problem.
Person2: If I flinch when you say you love me, it's both our problems. My confusion becomes your confusion. Students confuse teachers, patients confuse psychiatrists, lovers with confused hearts confuse lovers with clear hearts....

Person1: There's someone out there, Mack, I know, some man killing for the fun of it, sniffing human glue, without regard to age or sex, without predicable M.O. Someone who has a way to dispose of the bodies. You have access, you can call up local authorities, check morgues, conduct interviews. Be my man.
Person2: I already have an employer.
Person1: If you won't do it for me, do it for your cousin, Nadine, right? The girl in the pink sweater.
Person2: Who told you about her?
Person1: You did. You were with her when she disappeared, right? She took you to the mall or the movies, you turn around and she's gone.
Person2: It was the mall.
Person1: I know you, Lionheart. I watched your mind work, heard your dirty thoughts --
Person2: Those were just fantasies.

Person1: Eddie, is it all right if I get personal?
Person2: Whaddya been so far?
Person1: Eddie, you're a born loser.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: First time in ten years I ever saw Minnesota Fats hooked, really hooked. But you let him off.
Person2: I told you. I got drunk.
Person1: Sure, you got drunk. That's the best excuse in the world for losing. No trouble losing when you got a good excuse. And winning! That can be heavy on your back too. Like a monkey. You drop that load too when you got an excuse. All you gotta do is learn to feel sorry for yourself. It's one of the best indoor sports: feeling sorry for yourself -- a sport enjoyed by all, especially the born losers.
Person2: Thanks for the drink.
Person1: Wait a minute. Maybe I can help you.
Person2: To do what?
Person1: Get the three thousand. Play Minnesota Fats again.
Person2: Why?
Person1: Ten reasons. Maybe fifteen. And also there's something in it for me.
Person2: Oh yeah, I figured that. How much?
Person1: Seventy-five per cent.
Person2: For who?
Person1: For me.
Person2: That's a -- that's a pretty big slice. Who do you think you are, General Motors?
Person1: How much you think you're worth these days? I'm puttin' up the money, I'm puttin' up the time. For that I get seventy-five per cent return on my money -- if you win.
Person2: You think I can lose?
Person1: I never saw you do anything else.
Person2: You saw me beat Minnesota Fats for eighteen thousand dollars.
Person1: Look, you wanna hustle pool, don't you? This game isn't like football. Nobody pays you for yardage. When you hustle you keep score real simple. The end of the game you count up your money. That's how you find out who's best. That's the only way.
Person2: Why back me then? Why not back yourself? Go find yourself a big fat poker game and get rich. You know all the angles.
Person1: I'm already rich. But I like action. That's one thing I think you're good for is action. Besides, like I say... you got talent.
Person2: Yeah, you already told me that. You cut that slice down to bite-size and maybe we can talk.
Person1: No, we don't talk. I don't make bad bets. Seventy-five, twenty-five. That's it.
Person2: Kiss off.

Person1: Who did it?
Person2: Don't know.  But this guy's real damaged goods.  Iris knew someone was after her... and she said you were in danger too.  Now no more games, Faith.  Whatever you're hiding, whatever's going on, you have to get out of here now. Come with me right now.  Don't even think about it.
Person1: Then what?  Then what, Lenny?!  You going to protect me?  Big tough guy. You're a talker, Lenny.  You don't even have a gun.
Person2: I have a gun.  It's under my bed.
Person1: You don't know what you're messing with here.
Person2: Tell me.

Person1: My fault!  My fault!  This nut case goes out on a ledge and it's my fault?
Person2: If anything happens to John BUbber, Mister LaPlante I'm going to see you prosecuted to the full extent of the law.
Person1: What, is everybody in love with this, bozo?  I don't get this.  What about...?
Person2: Yes, everybody is in love with John Bubber.  The whole country, in fact. And they're not going to be happy if he jumps to his death because he was harassed by a lousy little money-grubbing low-life fence...
Person1: "Harassed."  Cause I yelled at him when he's riding in his limo?  The guy's a thief, he took my...
Person2: He had one tiny, uncharacteristic moment of weakness.  That's not the same thing as a lifetime of petty crime...
Person1: Hey, lady, I got faults, I know I'm not perfect but I don't get this at all, your attitude.  I saved your...
Person2: A lifetime of petty crime climaxed by your sleaziest accomplishment yet...  blackmailing a national hero...
Person1: -- saved your...  whaaaaaaat?  What? Blackmailing...?
Person2: You think I haven't figured it out? Just because the cops aren't on to you yet doesn't mean you're home free.  I'm a veteran reporter.  I've seen your kind before, the underbelly of crime.
Person1: Underbelly!
Person2: In all that smoke and fire, John had a moment of weakness.  He'd been down and out, destitute, living in his car.  It was just an impulse, stealing my purse.

Person1: Hey, I had a great time with Alex and Sam yesterday. They're really fun!
Person2: You shouldnâ€™t listen to or hang out with them. I've heard things, you know.
Person1: What things? They seemed nice to me.
Person2: Just trust me. You should spend more time with me and my friends instead.

Person1: According to my sources, the world will end on February 14, in the year 2016.
Person2: Valentine's Day.  That's got to be a bummer. Where did you get that date, Elaine?
Person1: I received this information from an alien.  I was at the Paramus Holiday Inn, I was having a drink in the bar when he approached me and started talking.  Then he must have used some sort of ray or a mind control device because he made me follow him to his room and that's where he told me about the end of the world.
Person2: Your alien had a room in the Holiday Inn?
Person1: It may have been a room on the spacecraft made up to look like a room in the Holiday Inn.  I can't be sure, Peter.
Person2: No, you can't, and I think that's the whole problem with aliens; you just can't trust them. You may get some nice ones occasionally like Starman or E.T., but most of them turn out to be some kind of lizard.  Anyway, we're just about out of time.  Next week on 'World of the Psychic,' hairless pets.  Until then, this is Peter Venkman saying ...  ... Good night.

Person1: You got three minutes. One second longer, I shoot your father in the face. Do you understand what I just said?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Do you believe me?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: You damn well better. Go.

Person1: Just souvenirs.  Towels and stuff.
Person2: You1re leaving, too?
Person1: I never wanted to hurt anybody.  In fact... I even thought I was helping.

Person1: There you are. Take some cake, why don't you?
Person2: No, thank you.
Person1: One little piece of cake won't hurt you. Go ahead, take one. It's full of fruit...citron, cherries and ginger. It'll make you dream. Yes, wonderful dreams.

Person1: Lasher touched you and you loved it.
Person2: It wes a dream...!
Person1: Just like your mother - and all the others that felt him - and used his power - and went to hell with a smile!
Person2: Stop it!
Person1: Witches. Rowan.  that is what we are.
Person2: ENOUGH!!!

Person1: See? And these are not just ordinary party-goers -- there are professionals in this crowd -- I didn't want any of them. You... You're what I want. Understand?
Person2: Yes...
Person1: Great. Now, what do you want to do about it?
Person2: Let's get naked.
Person1: You're on.

Person1: Do me a favor, Mitchell. Find yourself a nice secluded park bench.
Person2: Did I do something wrong?
Person1: I wouldn't know. Just do it somewhere else. There is such a thing as good manners.
Person2: How would you know, Brandon?
Person1: Want to walk out... or get thrown out?
Person2: You don't throw guests out, Brandon.
Person1: Don't bet on it. I'm eccentric.

Person1: We gotta face some facts here.
Person2: What facts are those?
Person1: I understand how it could happen.  I know why any guy would love her.  And I can't blame you that it happened.  You thought I was dead, she was grieving, you were trying to help her.
Person2: I was grieving too.
Person1: Yeah, right.  Anyway, you didn't know.
Person2: So what are you saying?
Person1: I'm saying now you do know.  So it's time for you to move on.
Person2: You left her.  How's that for a fact?
Person1: How's this for a fact?  I loved her first.

Person1: You're home late... or should I say early?
Person2: Why are you still here?  You killed a policeman.  You should leave! You'll bring ruin on my whole family.
Person1: They wouldn't have found me if you hadn't stolen the sword.  Like a little girl, you thought stealing would be fun?  You, too, are responsible for that death.  Come with me.  You don't want to waste your life as the wife of some bureaucrat.  Denied your talent... As a master and disciple we will rule.
Person2: I'll never live as a thief!
Person1: You're already a thief.
Person2: That was just for fun.  How can I leave?  Where would I go?
Person1: Wherever we want.  We'll get rid of anyone in our way.  Even your father.
Person2: Shut up!
Person1: It's the Giang Hu fighter lifestyle... kill or be killed. Exciting, isn't it?
Person2: I owe you nothing.
Person1: Yes, you do!  You are still my disciple.

Person1: I'm sorry, it was an accident.
Person2: When Ramesses destroyed Syria, it was an accident. You are a catastrophe! Why do I put up with you?

Person1: you crave what I might show you.  What you can learn.  What I can give you.  So much more than Michael can.
Person2: What Michael gives me is stronger than anything you could ever inderstand.
Person1: But I could understand. I want to understand!
Person2: I LOVE him!
Person1: Do not tell me that!
Person2: I LOVE MICHAEL.  MICHAEL!!

Person1: You can't do it alone, ya know.  It takes a mob of guys like you and enough money to make 'em look good.
Person2: We'll get by without 'em.
Person1: This isn't like playin' winos on the street.  You gotta do more than outrun the guy.
Person2: I never played for winos.
Person1: You gotta keep Lonnegan's con, even after you spent his money.  And no matter how much you take from his, he'll get more.
Person2: You're sacred of 'em, aren't ya?
Person1: Right down to my socks, turkey.  If I'da been half as scared a that lop-ear, I wouldn't a fallen asleep on 'em.  Lonnegan might kill me, but at least he won't bore me to death.
Person2: Then you'll do it?
Person1: If I can find a mob that'll risk it. But no matter what happens, I don't want you comin' back to me halfway through and sayin' it's not enough... cause it's all you got.

Person1: Come now, Sam.  This is a gathering of old friends.  I know how difficult this must be for you -- a man of your upbringing and integrity -- but now that I'm in charge I felt it was only fair that you finally know the truth.  After all, you're the only one around here who's still in the dark, as it were.  This isn't the way I wanted to tell you, but you've really given me no other choice.
Person2: This is madness, Wynn.
Person1: Your madness is another man's greatness.  This is the way things have always been.  You've just been too blinded by your own reality to see.  But having you on the outside has been convenient for us in many ways.  You always did come through -- our loyal watch dog. Finding him. Bringing him back to us once he'd finished his work.  Although after you had that nasty stroke the last time, I had to go after him myself.  And what a terrible time we had getting him out of that jail cell.
Person2: It was you.
Person1: Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar.
Person2: Why did you take Jamie?
Person1: She has the gift -- the blood of Thorn running through her veins.  Michael's mother had it, too.  So for six years I incubated her, prepared her for this night.  Michael has served his purpose.  And soon we will have a new progeny.
Person2: Jamie's baby ...
Person1: There you go trying to make sense again.  It's a curse.  Handed down through countless generations. As ageless as this celebration which you call Halloween.
Person2: Samhain.
Person1: And I'm its deliverer.  Its calling card, if you will.  I follow it.  Protect it. Act as its guardian.  In a sense, Sam, so do you.

Person1: You're dying to come into my room, aren't you?
Person2: You want me so bad, why don't you invite me?
Person1: Too proud to admit you're crazy about me, Dr. Jones?
Person2: I think you're too used to getting you own way, Willie...

Person1: Come on, admit it. K worried you, didn't he? He always worried you. In 1942, he's thirty-four years old, you're already fifty-six. And Goebbels and Goering keep saying to you, 'If you don't do it, little K will.' Never mind art and politics and symbols and airy-fairy bullshit about liberty, humanity and justice because I don't care how great you are. It's the oldest story in the book,  The ageing Romeo jealous of the young buck. The real reason you didn't leave the country when you knew you should have was that you were frightened that, once you were out of the way, you'd be supplanted by the Miracle Kid, the Party's boy twice over, flashy, talented little K.
Person2: This is absolute nonsense!
Person1: Well, I'm just beginning to develop my theme. Isn't that what you call it in classical music, developing your theme? Okay, so they played on your insecurity. That's human, understandable. But, there is one guy who doesn't like little K as much as he likes you - yeah, the number one man your old pal, Adolf. He thinks you're the greatest, and when he says, I want Wilhelm for my birthday, boy, they better go out get Wilhelm. So, Josef calls and threatens you with little K. And you said to hell with the Ninth in Vienna, I'll give it to Adolf as a birthday present in Berlin. That's the trick they played, they got you by the balls and they squeezed. Hard. Why did you stay? Why did you play for them? Why were you the flag-carrier for their regime?  Jealousy?
Person2: Of course there was a conspiracy against me, a campaign - even abroad.

Person1: Stu? Is that you? Where did you go?
Person2: Me? Nowhere. I was asleep.
Person1: Baby, don't lie. I know you went out.
Person2: Not me. Nope. You must've been dreaming.

Person1: Rasputin!  You're alive . . .
Person2: Despite being shot, poisoned and thrown into an icy river . . . YES!
Person1: I had nothing to do with it!
Person2: You gave the orders!
Person1: I did no such thing!
Person2: After all I've done for your family - YOU TRIED TO KILL MEEEEEE ! ! !

Person1: What the hell did you think you were doing?
Person2: You have a real gratitude problem. You know that, Bruce? I need a name. Batboy? The Dark Earl? What's a good side kick name?
Person1: How about Richard Grayson, college student?
Person2: ...I missed Two-Face by a heartbeat. When we catch him, you gotta let me kill him!
Person1: We don't kill. Killing is what damns you. It-. What am I talking about? This conversation is over. You're going away to school.
Person2: I saved your life. You owe me. So either you let me be your partner or I'm going after Harvey on my own.

Person1: Simple question, lieutenant.  No reason not to answer.  What is your father's name?
Person2: "Dad."
Person1: Any brothers?  Sisters?
Person2: Dick, Jane, and Spot.
Person1: Are you hungry?  What's your favorite food?  We'll try to get it for you.
Person2: Green Eggs and Ham.  You're not going to get anywhere.  You might as well put me in the cage.
Person1: You are in the cage, O'Neil.  Right here, right now.
Person2: Should I be afraid?
Person1: Right down to your worthless womb, and I'll tell you why.  This is my island.  My world.  And here I can get away with shit that would get me arrested anywhere else in the world. Take another scan of my little joy- boy outside.  If I can do that to a Navy Seal, what's gonna happen to you?  Huh?

Person1: You shouldn't even be mad at me over Sloan.
Person2: What you did is dead wrong.
Person1: Oh, is it?  Buddy boy, in this business if people don't produce, they get fired.
Person2: Sloan is the hardest working person I've ever met.
Person1: Let me ask you a question, if I may. How do you think she got the job in the first place?  I don't mean to burst your bubble, Mantan the Marvelous, but Sloan is an opportunity.

Person1: Now listen to what I've got to say. I took up this profession when I was ten years old. In those days there weren't these modern machines. The films were silent. But if they hadn't put Jesus Christ on a cross...You'd work Good Fridays too!

When I grew up, another war! Now it's all different. Times have changed. And you want to be a dope like me? Huh? Answer me!
Person2: No...

So I've been wasting my breath? You pretend to agree with me, but as soon as my back is turned, you do what you want!  Get out of here! I don't want to lay eyes on you again! This is the last straw! Your mother's right, you're crazy!!  But how'd he do it? The little bastard! By watching, he's learned! It's incredible!  I'm letting the box office know you're not to set foot even into the theatre! There are no more tickets for you! And I'm also talking to Father Adelfio! You won't be an altar boy any more either!!! You little runt!

Person1: Remember when you promised you'd help me with the project and then bailed?
Person2: Oh, that? Letâ€™s forgive and forget. We should focus on the present.
Person1: It's hard to forget when I had to pull an all-nighter because of that.
Person2: Always holding onto the past, aren't you?
Person1: It's about accountability and trust.
Person2: And it's about not holding grudges. We should move on.

Person1: I hear this Michael fellow is schizophrenic.
Person2: Mom, please.
Person1: Don't forget that Paul's a promising young attorney who loves you very much...
Person2: Mom, look, if I want to dump Paul, I'll dump him. If I want to screw Michael or live with him or marry him, then I'll do that.

Person1: You've always been so good to Li Mu Bai and me.  Please accept our thanks.
Person2: Please do not be such a stranger. You'll stay the night as my guest. Now, Shu Lien... tell me something. And forgive me for prying.  Your father was a great friend to me, and I think of you as my own daughter.
Person1: Please, Sir Te, what is it?
Person2: Li Mu Bai giving up his sword and his warrior days... maybe he's trying to tell you something?
Person1: I don't know...
Person2: Don't be coy.  I've always known about your feelings for each other. All these years, it's a shame... neither of you is brave enough to admit the truth to the other. You're both wasting precious time.
Person1: I beg your pardon.  Li Mu Bai and I aren't cowards.
Person2: When it comes to emotions, even great heroes can be idiots.  Tell me if Li Mu Bai is not more open the next time you see him.  I'll give him an earful!

Person1: What's outside of Pleasantville?
Person2: Look it doesn't matter. It's not important.
Person1: What is it?

Person1: And hello to you, too.
Person2: I called a fellow I know in Tulsa, the one who plays my chauffeur. There's a sucker there he says is made for us. And a boroker that just shut down, we can use their office, not change a thing! Now, I can scrape up ten grand without much trouble. That leaves fifteen or twenty for your end. We could start this weekend, get the sucker into position --
Person1: Wait a minute! When did this happen, that we're partners?
Person2: What?
Person1: The last I looked, we were just talking things over.
Person2: But the setup's there. It's there now.
Person1: I don't think I need it.
Person2: You're too good for the small-time, Roy. Move up to where there's big dough to be made, and you don't have to stick your neck out every day.
Person1: Maybe I like it where I am.

Person1: Now Amy
Person2: It's true.
Person1: And who did the voice belong to?
Person2: It was just a voice.
Person1: Now look, this is the last time you come to me with any such stories  I'm sick of this sort of thing.
Person2: Daddy, it's true.
Person1: Let me be the judge of that.

Person1: Yeah! Life's looking pretty damn good at the moment.
Person2: I don't know what happened to you, Jack ... but I can't believe you were always this much of a bastard.
Person1: When this boat finally reaches Jakata, I'll be first off. You'll never see me again ... and believe me - that day cannot come soon enough. I've got no problem with you ignoring me for the rest of the voyage.

Person1: If looks could kill, I'm dead...
Person2: No, I don't care about you -- you're fantastic.  My whole interest, if it's not too late, is in Susie...and how to undo what you've done to her...
Person1: And what have I done to her, besides not buy her a new fur coat lately?  Sidney, you were right -- the boy's a dilly.
Person2: Why?  Because I don't like the way you toy with human lives? - Your contempt and malice?  Because I won't be the accomplice of your sick ego - and the way it's crippled Susie...?  You think of yourself - you and your column - you see yourself as a national glory...but to me, and thousands of others like me, you and your slimy scandal, your phony patriotics - to me, Mr. Hunsecker, you are a national disgrace!
Person1: Son, I don't fancy shooting mosquitoes with elephant guns.  So suppose you just shuffle along and call it a day...

Person1: I -- hate -- you.
Person2: Well I guess that makes us even.
Person1: Ha!  Don't make me laugh.  You're crazy about me!  That's why you lied and cheated to get near me!
Person2: Oh come on, you're the one who came after me -- the swarthy, earthy, sensual worker!
Person1: I was slumming it!  I danced with you because you were the most pathetic specimen in the place!
Person2: Is that the same standard you used to choose General Formica?
Person1: I didn't choose him.  What kind  of idiot would...  ...choose who she wanted to marry?

Person1: Fear will keep you alive. Any one who is not afraid is bound to do something foolish, and bound to die.
Person2: What do you want with us?
Person1: Cooperation. If you try to escape, you will be met with automatic gunfire and a barricade of your comrade's bodies will prevent you from exiting. Good day.

Person1: Can't.  History report.  The Normans and the Saxons.
Person2: Bogutude.  Blow it off.
Person1: I really can't.  Besides, it's pretty interesting.
Person2: You're weird and I'm afraid of you. Seriously, Cassandra, there's a lot cooler things you could be doing than your homework.
Person1: Like what?
Person2: Like my homework.

Person1: I did another one last night.  You might have saved her, but you didn't want to play.
Person2: Where is she?
Person1: You'll find her.
Person2: If you got something to say to me, just come out and say it!

Person1: I looked for you back at the party, but you always seemed to be "occupied".
Person2: I was?
Person1: You never wanted to go out with 'me, did you?

Person1: What about the wife?
Person2: Clean.
Person1: Check his kids.
Person2: Clean.
Person1: Nobody's got clean kids.
Person2: We've got nothing, Bob.  This won't work.
Person1: If we find nothing, we get creative. Just make something up.  Instead of a couple weeks it'll be a couple of months.  The whole thing is under control.
Person2: You think we can keep this thing going for a couple of months!

Person1: To our assignment.
Person2: What is it you need me to do?
Person1: Helen, I want you to be my wife.
Person2: I'm married!
Person1: Just for the operation in Paris. I need to be married.  They'll be looking for a man traveling alone.
Person2: We're going to Paris?
Person1: Helen, there's a double agent in my outfit... I don't know who. There's no one I can trust. Except you.  Can you get away? Just for two days.
Person2: I don't know.  I have to think...
Person1: Here.  Sit down.  Be comfortable.

Person1: Who d'ya think you're foolin'?  I know you better than you think...
Person2: ...You're hurting me...

Person1: Can I give you a hand, beautiful?
Person2: I'm just going to my car?
Person1: That's right on my way.
Person2: My mother told me never to accept offers from strangers.
Person1: My name is Bobby.  Now I'm not a stranger anymore.  See how easy it is for us to get to know each other, beautiful?
Person2: Do you have to call me that?
Person1: I don't know your real name.
Person2: Maybe I don't want you to.

Person1: Do you want to se me working as a seamstress? Is that what you want? Do you want to see our fine things sold at an auction, our memories scattered to the winds? My God, Rose, how can you be so selfish?
Person2: It's so unfair.
Person1: Of course it's unfair! We're women. Our choices are never easy.

Person1: Mr Rothstein, sir, let me put her on suspension.
Person2: Never mind the 'sir'. Never mind the 'sir'.
Person1: Well, sir, I was just...
Person2: Why is she eight pounds over?
Person1: ...trying to offer you the respect that your...
Person2: I...
Person1: ...position...
Person2: 'Mr Rothstein' is good enough.
Person1: Mr Rothstein... well, sometimes, when you reach that pressure point, when you put that pressure point on them, you know, it shows...
Person2: She could at least lose half a pound or a quarter.  Listen...
Person1: ...and she doesn't always -
Person2: ...all you do is give me answers. Just - just give me the right answer.
Person1: But, sir. Well, I don't know why. I guess, maybe, because she's frightened that if she doesn't lose the weight she may even get fired.
Person2: That's right. She will get fired. In fact, I want you to send her back to Paris.
Person1: It's always been our policy -
Person2: No. Just stop everything.

Person1: Jesus Christ, is she for real?
Person2: Oh yes. I've read it over and over again. This baby's the real deal. Daddy's little angel. A paradigm of chastity and virtue.
Person1: B.F.D. What do you plan to do? Fly to Kansas and woo little Dorothy.
Person2: It just so happens we're not in Kansas anymore. Our little angel's father has accepted the new headmaster position at Oakwood. She's staying with my aunt up in Connecticut while Daddy sells his house. Can you imagine what this would do for my reputation? Screwing the new headmaster's virginal daughter before school starts? It will be my greatest victory.
Person1: You don't stand a chance. Even this is out of your league.
Person2: Care to make a wager on that?
Person1: I'll think about it...
Person2: Oh well, duty calls. Time to add another chapter to my work of art.

Person1: Maybe he's just a kooky guy who likes doing something kooky like that.
Person2: Maybe... why do you ask?
Person1: I'm thinking of investing with him. He worries me.
Person2: Why?
Person1: Maybe he's too flighty and irresponsible. That's why I asked if he was a fairy.
Person2: I don't know. He's a hairdresser.
Person1: You suggested it, don't you think it's a good idea?
Person2: Yes, but... I thought...
Person1: What?
Person2: That you were just indulging me.
Person1: No, doll, I listen to you. And if a deal loses money that's not so bad either if it's handled right.

Person1: Damn that Charlie I
Person2: It's not Charlie. It's me.
Person1: Peggy, let me ask you something.  You're not... expecting are you?
Person2: At my age? Don't be silly.
Person1: Thank God for that.
Person2: Dad.. it's not a big deal. Didn't you ever stay out all night when you were young?
Person1: Yes but I was a boy. And I still had hell to pay.
Person2: Calm down. Just listen for a minute.. Please.
Person1: All right. But this better be good.
Person2: I want to help with the family finances. I want you to buy some stocks. And gold. By 1980 gold is going to be worth eight hundred dollars an ounce. Then you sell.
Person1: Do you know how ridiculous you sound? First of all, it's illegal for U.S. citizens to buy gold. And in the second place, the price of gold is regulated by the government.
Person2: I think they're going to deregulate it.
Person1: That's your problems The more women think, the more trouble they get into.
Person2: Oh boy, that's another thing that's going to change. Who's going to think for us? Our husbands? You know, you treat Mom like a maid. It's not entirely your fault. Those were the attitudes in the fifties, and that's the way you raised me. But give Nancy a break, encourage her to go to art school.
Person1: I've heard just about enough of this lunacy! Go to your room!
Person2: Listen Dad, please. Buy IBM, buy Polaroid, buy Apple Computer. No, no. Not yet. Buy Xerox!
Person1: Evelyn, take her to her room!

Person1: That's too easy.  One minute you want to die, the next you want to live...  Do you think that life is a toy that can be played with and then broken when you don't want it anymore?
Person2: No, no... I'm just so tired, and lost, and... I didn't realize what I was doing!

Person1: Look -- you know who that is, Captain -- you know what she's saying -- you'll never see stuff that good outside of a magazine for the rest of your life.
Person2: I'm not that fond of blondes -- maybe I like brunettes --
Person1: Take your pick -- they all like you -- I can tell --
Person2: I like all of them --
Person1: Good -- like I said, take your pick.
Person2: I said I like all of them.
Person1: Now just a second -- I'm doing you a favor, buddy -- what're you trying to pull?

Person1: The army needs you.
Person2: The army can survive without me.
Person1: Then, I need you.  We all do. Without your victory the men would have no hope at all.
Person2: Someday, George, you may need to act for the good of the people no matter what Congress thinks that is.  It may come down to us, or them someday.  You or them.  Cicero was right. Was is "a time when the laws are silent"?
Person1: I hope I never have to believe that.
Person2: Christ, George, Joseph Reed's been writing letters back to Congress attacking you.  Your own aide!

Person1: He's working round the clock.  But the data needs to be tested, analyzed before --
Person2: Same old Reed.  All analysis, no action.  Wasn't that the problem with you two?

Person1: Elena, it's not what you think. It's not a big plot. Honestly. Honestly. I don't know if you want to go over this now, but it's just something that comes over me. I don't feel good about it. I know I've done what I didn't want to do. I don't know --
Person2: Well, I'm really pleased to hear a confession.
Person1: Elena, you're just getting wound up to get wound up.
Person2: Thanks for the diagnosis, Ben. Thank you. So let's just go to this fiasco if that's what you want to do. Let's just go on in. I'd rather talk to anyone else but you.

Person1: There, okay? Now that's just plain old hamburger.
Person2: Some of the brown stuff is still there.
Person1: Then eat around it.
Person2: No.
Person1: Now listen to me, young man. Do you know what I had to go through to put this goddamn food on the goddamn table?
Person2: I don't care.  I hate it.  I want pizza.
Person1: Not on your life.  That's it. I've had it with crap around this house.  From now on, no more pizza!  Get it?  Starting right now you can eat real food like a normal human being!
Person2: No!
technique: Brandishing Anger,Persuasion or Seduction,Shaming or Belittlement

dialogue:
Person1: Hello.
Person2: It's me.
Person1: I figured it was.  Where are you?
Person2: I think the big question here is where are you, if you don't mind my saying so, and I think I know where you are.  You're running.  On the run.  You're running from a point that everyone hits in any relationship, and you're just going to hit it again with Ian but it's going to be with a World Music bunny- rabbit-looking earth-shoe-wearing "Doctor Who"-watching twit who doesn't really understand you, not the way that I do and will more in the future, and you'll have just wasted more time and arrive in the exact same place that you're in now, only later. And with... him.
Person1: I'm not -- hold on...

Person1: Please!  I'll never let you down again, Mother.  Never.  I promise.
Person2: Then this shall be our little secret.  Remember that I see into thy soul as God sees.  Thou may fool the world. Even thy father.  But not me, Richard. Never me.
Person1: Mother, think of me always as your faithful dog ...

Person1: Now, Joe, you know it was all a mistake, don't you?
Person2: No, it wasn't, It was intentional.
Person1: Why would we want to hurt you?
Person2: Not you. Them.
Person1: Who?
Person2: I don't know Who.

Person1: The girl is looking to party, and you tell her we're going to go back to our motel room and crash? Jesus, Miles!
Person2: Well, I'm tired. Aren't you tired?
Person1: The chick digs you. She lit up like a pinball machine when she heard your novel was getting published.
Person2: Now I've got another lie to live down. Thanks, Jack.
Person1: I'm trying to get you some action, but you've got to help me out just a little bit.
Person2: Didn't seem to me like that's what was going on. You were all over her.
Person1: Somebody had to do the talking. And by the way, I was right. She's not married.
Person2: How do you know?
Person1: No rock. When she came to the bar, sans rock.

Person1: Private Johnson, are you unhappy in the Army?
Person2: No, sir--
Person1: Then how would you explain the fact that out of one hundred twenty people we tested, you're the only one who came up positive for drugs?
Person2: I'm sorry, sir.
Person1: When you were given the opportunity to enlist, a kind of contract was agreed upon. I think the Army has honored its part of that agreement.
Person2: Yes, sir--
Person1: Do you believe in what we're doing here, Private Johnson?
Person2: I-I can do the job, sir.
Person1: You don't sound too enthusiastic.
Person2: I am, sir.
Person1: What exactly do you think your job is, Private?
Person2: Follow orders. Do whatever they say.
Person1: Who's "they"?
Person2: The--the officers.
Person1: And that's the job? Nothing about serving your country?

Person1: Why did you go to the boss with that report without showing me first?
Person2: I thought it was the right thing to do. It was complete.
Person1: That was our project, Aria. You just threw me under the bus.
Person2: It wasn't like that. I just wanted to be efficient.
Person1: You will be sorry for this. Trust is hard to rebuild.
Person2: Derek, I didn't intend to sideline you. I hope we can move past this.

Person1: Yes there is.  I felt it this morning when I brought you the coffee.
Person2: Shit, here we go.
Person1: You didn't want to see me, did you?
Person2: If there is one thing I can't stand about sleeping with women, it's all the mind reading.
Person1: What are you afraid of?
Person2: I'm not afraid of anything.
Person1: I don't understand - ?
Person2: I know!  You can't understand, because we're different, Violet.  We're different.
Person1: We're not that different, Corky.
Person2: How can you sit in that bed and say that?
Person1: Because it's the truth.
Person2: Let me guess.  This is where you tell me that what matters is on the inside.  That inside you, there is a little dyke just like me?
Person1: Oh no, she's nothing like you.  She's a lot smarter than you.
Person2: Is that what her daddy tells her?
Person1: I know what I am.  I don't need to have it tattooed on my shoulder.
Person2: What are you saying?  That you don't have sex with men?
Person1: I don't.
Person2: For Christ's sake, Violet!  I heard you!  Thin walls, remember?
Person1: What you heard wasn't sex.
Person2: What the heck was it?
Person1: All my life, everyone has been telling me that when I have sex, I'm not really having sex.  Not real sex. But they're wrong.  I know what is and isn't sex and what you heard was definitely not sex.
Person2: What was it then?
Person1: Work.

Person1: You said 48 hours!
Person2: I never agreed to that.
Person1: Bob, you're lying!
Person2: Bullshit.
Person1: All right! Backyard! Right now!

Person1: Who knew she was pregnant?
Person2: Why do you insist upon pressing...
Person1: Was it you?
Person2: Is it because she's a nun?
Person1: Did you know she was pregnant?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And you didn't send her to a doctor.
Person2: I didn't guess until it was too late.
Person1: For what?  An abortion?
Person2: Oh, don't be ridiculous.
Person1: Too late for what?
Person2: I don't know... too late to stop it.
Person1: The baby?
Person2: The scandal...
Person1: You went to the room to help with the birth.
Person2: She didn't want any help.
Person1: You wanted that child out of the way.
Person2: That's a lie.
Person1: You hid the wastepaper basket in her room.
Person2: I didn't hide it. I put it there for the blood and the dirty sheets.
Person1: And the baby.
Person2: No!
Person1: You tied the cord around its neck.
Person2: I wanted her to have it when no-one else was around, they would have taken the baby to a hospital and left it with them, but it was such a difficult birth, there was so much blood and I panicked.
Person1: Before or after you killed the child?
Person2: I left it with her and I went for help.
Person1: I doubt that's what she'd say.
Person2: Then she's a liar.

Person1: It's a very nice letter. But I have to go with what's best for the students.
Person2: What does that mean?
Person1: I need someone to work on budget projections.
Person2: Office work?
Person1: Or, of course, you could take a sabbatical the rest of the year.

Person1: Greg, someone told me you claimed I wanted the team reshuffled.
Person2: Well, based on our chat yesterday, it sounded like it.
Person1: That is not what I said. You're twisting my words.
Person2: Maybe you should be clearer next time. Everyone's confused now.

Person1: Never answer the phone.  Ever.
Person2: Tsk, believe me, this will be the last time.
Person1: Did you buy some clothes?
Person2: I got a dress, yeah.
Person1: Just one?  Christ... I hope it's appropriate.
Person2: It's very tasteful.  I think you'll especially like the zipper in the crotch.  I'm -- joking.
Person1: Let's hope so.  You'll get some more clothes tomorrow.  I'll be pushed for time so meet me in the hotel lobby at seven forty-five sharp.  Got it?
Person2: No, I don't "got it".  Even the farmboys back in Georgia come to the door when they're taking you on a date.
Person1: This isn't a date.
Person2: Go by yourself then.  Where you taking me anyway?
Person1: The Rex.
Person2: Any good?
Person1: I think you'll approve.
Person2: ... all right.  I'll meet you in the lobby.  But only cause you're paying me to.
Person1: Thank you very much.

Person1: You idiot! Why do you think I use you?... To be a walking advertisement.
Person2: I'm sorry, Mike. I never heard of LaMarra flipping on anyone before. He said he had the cops paid off. Antonucci never flipped on anyone before. He had the cops paid off.
Person1: Not the cop that showed up at my door!
Person2: What happened, Mike.
Person1: You don't want to know.

Person1: Every time we discuss our plans, you mention that one time I changed our holiday destination.
Person2: Because it felt like my opinion didn't matter.
Person1: I've apologized countless times. I donâ€™t get why you wonâ€™t let this go.
Person2: Maybe if you started valuing our decisions together, I would.
Person1: Constantly bringing it up makes me feel trapped in one mistake.
Person2: And I feel unheard.

Person1: Twelve Young, I don't have time for your games. Now answer me or do I have to come out there myself?
Person2: I usually don't do calls before coffee. But I think it might do you some good.  Twelve Young is here and I'm gonna take care of you, baby. Don't you worry about a thing, yahear, cause Marcus is alive and on arrival.
Person1: I'm not your baby, Young, I'm not your mother either. You're going to a cardiac arrest, Avenue C and Ninth, northeast corner. It's a club. Take the side entrance.
Person2: Ten-four, hon.  This is for you.

Person1: Get out of this room and get back to work.
Person2: I don't have to listen to you anymore.
Person1: I am in charge now. Get back to work or I'll fire you.
Person2: Let me ask you Mr. Manager, do you notice a smell of cockroaches? If I were to leave this room, I'm sure I could find this smell. I know people who could cleanse it. But maybe it doesn't bother you? Why is that? Are used to this smell? Not me, I need a clean room to escape it.

Person1: Hey, now wait a sec...
Person2: Now he's going to launch into his rap about how he's just doing his job; following orders.  Friends, let me tell you about another bunch of hate mongers that were just following orders. They were called Nazis, and they practically wiped a nation of people from the Earth... just like cigarettes are doing now! Cigarette smoking is the new Holocaust, and those that partake in the practice of smoking or sell the wares that promote it are the Nazis of the nineties! He doesn't care how many people die from it! He smiles as you pay for your cancer sticks and says, "Have a nice day."
Person1: I think you'd better leave now.
Person2: You want me to leave? Why? Because somebody is telling it like it is? Somebody's giving these fine people a wake-up call?!
Person1: You're loitering in here, and causing a disturbance.
Person2: You're the disturbance, pal! And here...  I'm buying some... what's this?... Chewlie's Gum. There. I'm no longer loitering. I'm a customer, a customer engaged in a discussion with other customers.

Person1: Bill, I...
Person2: DON'T SAY "BILL," BERNIE!  DON'T SAY ONE WORD!  DIDN'T I SAY "ONE WORD AND YOU'RE FIRED?"
Person1: I...
Person2: YOU KNOW WHY?  BECAUSE IT'LL BE AN EXCUSE!  IT'LL BE "BERNIE LAPLANTE EXCUSE NUMBER FOUR THOUSAND ONE HUNDRED AND SIX."  NO, FOUR THOUSAND ONE HUNDRED AND TWELVE.  THAT'S HOW MANY EXCUSES YOU HAVE GIVEN ME, I KEEP TRACK OF THEM ELECTRONICALLY. I HEARD THEM ALL, BERNIE.
Person1: Bill, I got some legal problems and I...
Person2: THAT'S IT!  YOU TALKED!  YOU'RE FIRED!  OUTTA HERE!  GET OUTTA HERE!
Person1: Bill, listen...
Person2: OUT!  I TOLDJA.  JESUS CHRIST, I GOT CUSTOMERS WAITING!  AN' YOU WERE GONNA GO OUT LIKE THAT?  AND MEET THE PUBLIC IN STOCKING FEET?
Person1: Bill, I got financial problems and...
Person2: I DON'T CARE ABOUT YOUR PROBLEMS, I'M GONNA THINK ABOUT MY PROBLEMS. YOU'RE ONE A MY PROBLEMS.  GET OUT! OUT!  OUT!

Person1: I'm sorry. She misunderstood, that's all.
Person2: But you tell me you had a pleasant visit and your mother says you were sullen and uncommunicative. Whom do you think I should believe?
Person1: Doctor, I hate to break this to you, but my mother is a little batty.
Person2: Frances, you're still filled with anxiety. You feel guilty and hostile toward your family and friends. Consequently, I didn't recommend your release at the staff review.
Person1: You what?
Person2: Mental illness is an elusive thing, and though I'm pleased you're feeling more... capable, it's perhaps unrealistic to expect you to be completely cured after so short a time. Don't you agree?

Person1: You guessed wrong.
Person2: You only think I guessed wrong --  -- that's what's so funny! I switched glasses when your back was turned. You fool.

Person1: Are you making an ass of yourself?
Person2: There's only you, Ryan.  You know what, Ryan?  You're beautiful.  I love you so much... You need...
Person1: I don't need a drug.
Person2: You need a good review and you'll be fine.  The whole color of the world will change, mark my words.

Person1: I've known soldiers who've had their heads blown off who were more intelligent than you two.  Not only have you failed to protect your most valuable possession from theft - but you didn't even know it'd been stolen!  I'd sooner buy heroin from the guy who sells drugs outside my grandson's school than anything from you guys.
Person2: I am sorry you feel that way.
Person1: And I'm sorry you look that way, short-ass.  That suit stinks and you obviously dye your hair.

Person1: We'll sleep here tonight. You'll come home with me. We'll let the house, and the lands too; plenty of willing neighbors.
Person2: I don't want to leave.
Person1: Didn't want your father to die either, did ya? But it happened.

Person1: Mrs. Mulwray, do you love your husband?
Person2: ...Yes of course.
Person1: Then go home and forget about it.
Person2: But...
Person1: I'm sure he loves you, too. You know the expression, let sleeping dogs lie? You're better off not knowing.
Person2: But I have to know.

Person1: I just want to be clear about one thing.  I used to work for him, but now I work for you.  I'm not a partisan person, I'm an issue person.
